text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with oxtail ragout that's right the
only thing my audience likes more than
when things come out perfectly is when
they don't and I'm not exactly sure why
people enjoy it so much when I do screw
up
who knows maybe it's the occasional
mistake that makes people think I'm just
like them which of course I'm not
but anyway despite one of the dumbest
cooking decisions I've made in a long
time
this still came out incredibly delicious
mostly thanks to these so we will start
this recipe by getting some towel
oxtail to be exact and while I really do
wish it came from oxen it doesn't this
is nothing more than the cut-up tail of
a big old cow and if you never work with
this before it is one of the most
flavorful most gelatinous cuts of meat
on the entire cow which means two things
a ton of flavor and then it takes a
really really really really really long
time to cook and because my plan here
was to cook this in some tomato sauce
for a pasta I wanted to brown it very
well first like we usually do but
because of the odd shape of these pieces
it isn't that easy to brown in a pan so
I decided to do it in a very hot oven
instead so I seasoned it very thoroughly
with salt and freshly ground black
pepper and place it on a bed of chopped
onions which contained a little bit of
garlic and I popped that in a nice hot
oven 425 for about 45 minutes to an hour
or until it was very nicely browned and
yes I did turn out half way through and
as you can see that how'd oven did a
very nice job at caramelizing that meats
much more thoroughly than we could have
done with a pan and at this point we
would normally transfer all this into
our sauce pot add the rest of the
ingredients and simmer till tender but
that's not what happened because I had
what I thought was a brilliant idea I
thought to myself why not just dump all
the sauce ingredients into this pan and
finish this in the oven is a braised
dish man that's genius
why hasn't anyone else thought of this
so I dumped in a little bit of wine
vinegar which is to balance what is a
very sweet meat as well as some tomato
sauce I also went ahead and added some
chicken broth and by the way ox tails
are so flavorful you really can just use
water but I had a little stock to use up
so I tossed it in so that's up to you
you guys are the boss of it eventually
no matter what you use will be an
incredibly delicious sauce I also had
some fresh herbs around so I tossed in
some rosemary thyme and oregano
and then I finished up with some kosher
salts as well as some chili flakes and
once I had that seasoned up I continued
on with this ill-fated strategy which
included covering this up with a piece
of crinkled up parchment paper
if you crinkle it up it's easier to work
with and what that does is kind of cover
and protect the product in the pan as
well as allow for evaporation which is
of course going to help concentrate the
flavors so I covered that up and popped
it in a nice slow oven about 311 for a
couple hours at which point I pulled it
out to take a look and basically what I
discovered is that what was happening
was not much I mean it kind of looked
like stuff was happening the meat was
taking on a dark and dangerous looking
color which is generally a good thing
but as soon as I started turning these
with the tongs I could feel they were
still very very hard and firm and they
sort of felt like hockey pucks so became
clear at this point these were going to
need a lot more time and I did start
having second thoughts and was actually
considering stopping and transferring
these into a pot and simmering them as
per usual
but unfortunately my stubbornness
trumped by common sense pardon the
expression and I decided after turning
them over I would pop them back in
without the paper for a couple more
hours to see what would happen and by
the way in case you're wondering why I'm
not doing those little captions with the
times and temperatures well that's
because you guys are not going to do
this step so I popped it in for a few
more hours at which point I pulled it
out to check and it was deja vu all over
again
as soon as I felt them with the tongs I
realize these are still not even close
to being cooked but just to get a second
opinion I went ahead and checked with a
knife anyway so it looks like it slides
in nicely but I could definitely feel it
wasn't tender enough and that meat was
still very much attached to the bone
okay if you only remember one thing from
this video it's the ox tails are not
really edible until that meat will pull
easily and cleanly off the bone so was
it this moment that I finally admitted
defeat and went ahead and transferred
everything into a sauce pot as I should
have done from the beginning and I even
rinsed out that goodness from the
roasting pan with a little more stock
and once I got everything into the pot I
felt a lot better so to summarize we are
going to do the beginning step where we
Brown our ox tails wither on your
mixture but once that's been done you're
just going to transfer everything into
this pot and simmer it on low until very
very tender which believe it or not
take about four or five hours depending
on the size I mean these actually
required a couple more hours of
simmering even though these had been in
the oven forever besides waiting and
waiting for them to get tender the only
other thing you're going to have to do
is probably skim some fat from the top
oxtails are going to release a
tremendous amount of fat so I do like to
skim almost all that off but really
that's all you got to do just skim off
the fat give it a stir once in a while
and simply wait for it to be done and
how you know your oxtails have cooked
long enough is this
if you grab one of the larger pieces and
take a fork and the meat will kind of
pull off the bone clean like this you
are done I know finally and of course
because you've watched countless
hundreds of food wishes videos you know
you got to grab a spoon and taste this
before you serve it in case it needs any
more salt or spice or whatever and mine
was fine
I had adjusted it off-camera which meant
I was ready to serve up on some rigatoni
and some people like to do an extra step
here and actually pull all that meat off
the bone and put it back in but
personally I much prefer this
presentation plus I've always felt
things taste a little better when you
have to do a little bit of work to get
the meat which is why I've always
considered oxtail sort of the lobster of
beef but anyway I'm going to serve that
up on some pasta with a little bit of
extra sauce and then I finished up with
a nice gradient of parmigiano-reggiano
as well as some freshly chopped to tell
you parsley and as the wise man once
said all's well that ends well in man
did this end well speaking of old
sayings have you ever heard the one that
goes the closer the bone the sweeter the
meat it was ox tails that made me
realize what that actually means since
for me this is by far the most flavorful
most beefy sweetest richest most
succulent meat on the entire cow or ox
for that matter so yes my attempt to
braise these in a low oven was a big
failure but this eventually came out so
deliciously I didn't care I mean come on
what do we do in here anyway we're here
to have fun learn things and for me
personally continue to avoid actual work
so no harm no foul as I sneak in one
last cliche and I should mention if you
eat this with a knife and a fork you can
get every little scrap off those bones
really easily but I actually prefer
another method instead of getting a
knife dirty for no reason once I'm done
working those are
with the fork I simply pick those up and
suck every last succulent scrap of meat
off that vertebrae it is a lot of fun
and delicious and quite a scene
so with that visual in mind I'll finish
up by saying I really do hope you give
these a try soon so head over to food
wishes comm for all the ingredients and
more info as usual and as always enjoy
